data.text: Using a Friction Shifter on a Touring Bicycle?

Friction shifters anyone? Been have a lot of shifting issues lately and am thinking about putting bar end friction shifters on my Trek 520 instead of the brake/shift integrated levers. Has anyone here switched to friction shifters on their touring bike? Pros and cons?
F.

data.text: well, I didn't "switch" but my 1984 Fuji Touring V still has friction/Indexed barcons and they work just as well as my newer bike with integrated shifter/brakes. data.text: How about Gevenalle brifters. Basically a great brake lever with any permutation of rear index/friction and up to 3 x in front. I am a huge fan of also of Silver shifters from Soma- a bit hard to get (maybe Rivendell) Touring is hard on shifters. Friction is great. It will get you home and allow you to correct for all sorts of ills- bent cages, bent hangers, kinked cables. Btw the Gevenalle shifts have a unique feature of going easy to hard front and back in the same direction. You are basically mounting a downtube shifter on a brake lever. Index to friction requires a 4 mm lever and a click of a ring. Takes about 10 seconds. If you are 9 speed- shimano ultegra bar ends are the bomb.

data.text: The shifting issues are because your cables are old and frayed Change all your cables and sleeves. And add a lightweight oil not WD-40. Your friction shifters will work like new. The installation of index shifters would be better.Always store you bike with chainring in 1 and gears in 1. No tension on springs or cables. Your derailleurs and cables will last longer. And adjustment or bike shop tune ups will be less.
data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: Nothing wrong with friction shifters if they are maintained . New new cables and sleeves ever few years. Remember you do not have to use barrel adjusters to get rid of ticking and rings or gears changing on there own.

data.text: your granny in front and smallest on back. Cable should. Have no pressure on them just snug. If you have considerably pressure on the smallest may because your cables are getting old and have stretched . Then at tune ups barrel adjustment has tightened to get it to shift as smith as can be when go up to your climbing gear in rear. You may have it chatting also. Cables get old and also stretchy over the years. Always change cable sleeves when you do this unless on the road. I carry an extra cable with me in long trips. If you are in a very hilly area and the back cable breaks . You could have almost an impossible gear range to use. Your rear cassette will go to the smallest 11 or 12 . You can go to the end of the sleeve and use a small vice grip to put chain in a middle gear. Or push over by hand the derailer and adjust the stop. You will now have a manageable 3 speed with trips. And 2 speed if compact. It the front cable goes you can still ride it will go to granny.

data.text: That will eliminate the shifter indexes, & thereby eliminate the problem of them being out of sync, but IMHO you should just sync them (if them being out of sync is even the problem). It is quite possible that your derailleurs are simply out of adjustment, or your chain is just too old & worn or even just too dirty & stiff, or a cable is just frayed or dirty or jumped out of track. In other words you might very easily either byass your problem & bring it within your expertise to adjust, OR you might waste time & money chasing the wrong problem only to finally learn what you are currently avoiding. I think you should at least confirm the problem before you try to fix it. On the other hand, firing the parts & service bazooka in a wild guess can be educational too.
